avalancheActivity.highlights: Off-piste activities call for caution and restraint. Along the border with France and along the border with Switzerland the avalanche prone locations are larger.
avalancheActivity.comment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind from northerly directions, large wind slabs formed in the last two days.
New snow and wind slabs can as before be released by a single winter sport participant. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and in extremely steep terrain. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack indicate an unfavourable avalanche situation, caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.

Fresh snow and large quantities of wind-drifted snow of the last few days are in some cases still prone to triggering. As a consequence of warming and solar radiation, the natural activity of small and medium dry and moist avalanches will gradually increase, in particular on rocky sunny slopes, as well as at the base of rock walls in particular below approximately 2900 m.

snowpackStructure.comment:
40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days above approximately 2000 m.
The wind was strong to storm force. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in particular on shady slopes. The snowpack is unfavourably layered.
Tuesday: Several medium-sized to large dry slab avalanches have been released as a consequence of the strong northwesterly wind. Natural avalanches and avalanches triggered by explosives confirm the unfavourable bonding of the snowpack.
In all aspects snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2000 m, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Shady slopes: The old snowpack is faceted and weak.

tendency.highlights: As a consequence of rising temperatures and solar radiation and the light to moderate wind, the snow drift accumulations will stabilise during the next few days. The danger of moist avalanches will increase a little during the day.

avalancheActivity.highlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
avalancheActivity.comment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind, large surface-area wind slabs formed in the last few days in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
They can as before be released, even by a single winter sport participant, caution is to be exercised in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. Above the tree line these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack indicate a sometimes unfavourable avalanche situation on wind-loaded slopes.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.

As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on extremely steep sunny slopes below approximately 2900 m.

snowpackStructure.comment:
15 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days above approximately 2000 m.
As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind from northerly directions, deep wind slabs formed in the last two days. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on top of a weakly bonded old snowpack in particular on shady slopes above approximately 2000 m.
In all aspects snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2200 m, depending on the infuence of the wind. Adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas above approximately 2200 m hardly any snow is lying.
Shady slopes: The snowpack consists of faceted crystals.

tendency.highlights: As a consequence of rising temperatures and solar radiation and the light to moderate wind, the snow drift accumulations will stabilise during the next few days. The danger of moist avalanches will increase a little during the day.

avalancheActivity.highlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
avalancheActivity.comment:
As a consequence of a strong wind from northeasterly directions, rather small wind slabs formed in the last few days in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The small quantity of fresh snow as well as the small wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack on shady slopes. These can be released, especially at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, caution is to be exercised in particular in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable).

As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist avalanches being released will increase gradually on extremely steep sunny slopes.

snowpackStructure.comment:
10 to 15 cm of snow fell in the last few days above approximately 2000 m.
As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind from northerly directions, mostly small wind slabs formed. The wind slabs are clearly recognisable.
In all aspects snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2200 m, depending on the infuence of the wind. Below approximately 1900 m from a snow sport perspective, insufficient snow is lying. On steep sunny slopes below approximately 2500 m a little snow is lying.
The snowpack is not distinctly layered. Shady slopes: The snowpack consists of faceted crystals.

regions.name: B - VALLI DI GRESSONEY, AYAS, CHAMPORCHER
